captions.text:
Ah, Psychonauts, what a great game that was. I 
hope your fingers are still smarting from the

last time I had to bring that across. Sure, the 
platforming physics were a bit jank and all the

characters looked like their concept art had been 
scanned in by someone with Parkinson&#39;s disease,

but it was funny and well written and weird 
because it was a Tim Schafer game from that

wonderful golden age of the PS2 era when games 
could be weird and culty I SAID CULTY because

they weren&#39;t expected to make enough money to 
pay for the CEO&#39;s moon expedition. Unfortunately

they were still expected to make some amount 
of money and that&#39;s where Psychonauts 1 fell

short on initial release, and why I had to start 
breaking fingers. Fortunately the Double Fine have

managed to cling to driftwood long enough to wait 
for the inevitable twenty year nostalgia wave to

come around and can now surf that driftwood all 
the way to sex island with Psychonauts 2. Yes,

they&#39;ve pulled what&#39;s now technically known as 
the Shenmue gambit. And you know, slipping on

those old familiar Psychonauts trousers I could 
almost think no time had passed at all. I mean,

in the game world, it literally hasn&#39;t, but 
nevertheless. Very little about the look and feel

of the world seems to have changed much. Here&#39;s 
all those clashing colour schemes we remember

so fondly, and all the old characters exactly 
as we remember, still designed like plasticine

models after they&#39;ve been peeled out of a waffle 
iron. Ooh, that fine praise was a trifle damning,

wasn&#39;t it. Psychonauts 2 certainly has the vibe 
of a sequel the creators had been hoping to make

right after the first one after it had made them 
rich and respected by their peers. The mechanics

have barely changed at all and the plot deals with 
a lot of loose strands that were dangling off the

first game like hairs on a teenage boy&#39;s chin. 
Psychonauts 1, a game about a summer camp for

trainee psychic commandos, felt like we were 
glimpsing a larger world of psychic politics

through the narrow perspective of a child, like a 
birthday party at a McDonalds themed around Seal

Team Six. In Psychonauts 2 the horizons broaden as 
our protagonist Raz enters the adult world of the

Psychonauts and must start from the bottom rung of 
the intern programme. For you see, while the look

and feel of Psychonauts hasn&#39;t changed much, one 
significant difference is that the people creating

it have aged about twenty fucking years, and 
Crikey Seamus O&#39;Testicles does that come across

at times. Where the first game focussed on a group 
of kids Raz&#39;s age and their children&#39;s problems

like bullying and having to go to the psychotic 
dentist, Raz&#39;s fellow interns are all disaffected

teenage Extreme Ghostbusters rejects and the plot 
isn&#39;t even about them, much, they just sort of

pop up as a convenient peer group whenever Raz 
needs someone to get embarrassed in front of,

it&#39;s almost like they&#39;re teenagers in a game being 
written by people who don&#39;t really identify with

young people anymore. Which might also explain 
why the plot eventually focusses squarely on the

original founders of the Psychonauts, and Raz 
having to fix their doddery old Farrah Fawcett

liking brains so they can help him defeat their 
onetime nemesis, so from the halfway point of the

plot we suddenly have to stop giving a toss about 
any established characters and exclusively reserve

our tosses for the backstories and inner worlds 
of these hitherto unexplored vintage scrotes.

It&#39;s like if most of the second half of The Last 
Crusade was devoted to a flashback about Indiana

Jones&#39; dad. Yes, I&#39;m sure Indiana Jones&#39; dad 
had a jolly interesting and storied life but

I&#39;m kinda here to watch Indiana Jones biff Nazis 
and snog hotties and the closest his dad gets to

snogging hotties is adding tabasco to his Sunday 
brunch bloody mary. It&#39;s a switcharoo on the first

game where the kids were fully characterised and 
most of the adults were merely props. When we were

having to explore and fix the mental realms of 
dudes who thought they were Napoleon or that the

milkman was spying on them and in all it was 
an accurate and sensitive depiction of mental

illness the way Jabba the Hutt was an accurate 
and sensitive depiction of thyroid issues.

After twenty years we clearly want to go about 
things with more maturity, so this wacky comedy

game about psychic spies who look like the cast 
of Gumby after they got rescued from a horrendous

sink disposal accident feels it has to visualise a 
character&#39;s struggles with alcoholism and anxiety

with sympathy and seriousness rather than as a 
vehicle for a string of silly gags. Thing is,

though, I like silly gags. Christ knows there 
haven&#39;t been enough of those since September 10th,

2001 when human society officially peaked. 
Speaking as someone with a brain that&#39;s a

fixer-upper on a good day, I care more about 
having a laugh than you paying sufficient respect

to people with anxiety disorders and their flag 
and national anthem. I Wanna Be Sedated by The

Ramones, if you&#39;re interested. My point is, for me 
Psychonauts 2 suffers from having lost its cynical

edge. Rather than fuck with a mad person&#39;s head 
so he firebombs a hospital we must now acknowledge

the admittedly fucked up ethics of going into 
someone&#39;s brain and rewriting their personality.

And then we must all learn an important lesson 
and apologise and forgive each other and everyone

gets extra marshmallows in their cocoa that 
night. Not that there&#39;s anything wrong with

that. Marshmallows are nice. But I knew the ethics 
were fucked, I assumed that was the big joke, that

they were teaching wholesome apple-cheeked summer 
camp kids the art of hands-free lobotomisation.

And I struggle to recall parts of Psychonauts 2 
that really stand out as comedy highlights the

way stuff like the milkman conspiracy did in the 
first game. Maybe the one chapter that&#39;s about

as obviously about taking drugs as you can get 
without ever directly mentioning taking drugs,

and that&#39;s more about the metajoke, anyway. 
Ethics? Metajokes? Stop wanking off that grammar

school education you didn&#39;t even finish Yahtzee 
and tell me and my easily distracted moron friends

if you recommend the sodding game. Well obviously 
I do, unless you consider any of Psychonauts 1&#39;s

gameplay issues to be deal breakers because 
they&#39;re all back and ready to flick your ears

anew. Hey there fiddly combat. Good to see 
you, annoying platforming physics where you

waste half an hour trying to jump off a slippery 
two inch perch to grab one last collectible with

no actual fucking use. Why didn&#39;t you ever call, 
extremely limited equip slots for traversal powers

so you have to constantly go to the menu and swap 
them around like a partially deaf switchboard

operator? But if you can deal with that then yes 
I recommend because it&#39;s the rest of the story

that Psychonauts 1 left hanging and however you 
shape it it&#39;s a significant net increase in the

amount of Psychonauts that exists in the world 
and that can only be a good thing. But while I

came away from it satisfied, the topmost thought 
in my head afterwards was &quot;Gosh, I should replay

Psychonauts 1,&quot; and that&#39;s not necessarily 
what you want from a sequel. It means that it

evoked the original without managing to eclipse or 
transcend it. It&#39;s like I stuck my dick in a sofa

cushion and had a lot of fun with it but secretly 
the whole time I was thinking about the armchair.
